seasonal: November is one of the two most bearish months of the year for oil seasonally. In the last 30 years, oil closed on Nov 29 at a price LOWER than on Nov 10 in approximately 73% of cases (22 out of 30 years). Seasonal downward bias is strong.

statistics.description: Multi-decade seasonal statistic over the last 30 years: approximately 70% probability of upward movement on Nov 7
Multi-decade seasonal statistic over the last 30 years: approximately 82% probability of downward movement on Nov 11 - strongest statistical signal in the entire report
Multi-decade seasonal statistic over the last 30 years: approximately 67% probability of upward movement on Nov 19
In the last 30 years, oil closed on Nov 29 at a LOWER price than on Nov 10 in 73% of cases (22 out of 30). Strong end-of-month bearish statistic.

insights: No monthly cycles are active for November oil, but a strong weekly cycle is peaking around the week ending Nov 21 - this is the dominant cycle and turning date Nov 20 aligns with it
The daily turning date of Nov 20 coincides with the weekly cycle, which should be considered for potential significant direction change or notable volatility
Multi-year support band between $64.40-$66.50 per barrel continues to serve as a turning point for the current month as well
The picture for the medium-term remains a swing between consolidation and decline - not yet a challenged support on the weekly chart, but price remains below key structure

In the weekly view, conditions for a true reversal from decline to rally remain unfulfilled: a move above $70 per barrel is the first step, and only a strong sustained move above $80 would confirm the end of the bearish trend and open the door for a new bullish phase
As long as this does not happen, continuation downward remains the more probable scenario

In a bearish scenario, the first target is around the previous low near $55.30, and in continuation between $51-$52.70 per barrel - a clear break of these levels opens potential for deeper decline to the central support area near $43.40 per barrel

An additional observation from the weekly chart reveals a persistent pattern: the 20-week moving average continues to function as a buffer alternating between support and resistance against every attempt by oil to return to a bullish trend
While the 50-week moving average continues to decline and serves as a dynamic barrier against any attempt to shift to a positive trend
All key levels are marked on the attached charts

resistance.description: First resistance area on the daily chart
Resistance zone from the weekly chart / multi-year support-turned-resistance
Key resistance with 50-day moving average area - clearing this is the first step toward bullish reversal
Major resistance - only a sustained break above confirms end of bearish trend

technical.indicators: Weekly chart shows a persistent downtrend with the 20-week moving average acting as dynamic resistance and the 50-week moving average declining. The daily chart shows the 50-day moving average around $69-70 acting as resistance. Price is in a range between $59-$66 support/resistance band. No monthly cycles are active but a strong weekly cycle peaks around Nov 21. Overall bearish structure remains intact unless $70+ is reclaimed, and the Nov 20 turning date aligning with the weekly cycle peak makes it a critical observation point.

summary: Oil enters November 2025 with a strong seasonal bearish bias - historically one of the two worst months of the year, with a 73% probability of closing lower at month end compared to Nov 10. No monthly cycles are active but a strong weekly cycle peaking around Nov 21 aligns with the daily turning date of Nov 20, making this a critical juncture. The multi-year support band at $64.40-$66.50 continues to be relevant, while a move above $70 is needed for any bullish reversal signal. The Nov 11 date carries the strongest statistical signal in the entire report with 82% probability of decline.
previous_month_review: October 2025 had five turning dates for oil. First date (Oct 3) served as the low and initiated a rally of approximately 5% to the next date. Second date (Oct 10) arrived one day early (Oct 9) and served as the high - an approximately 8% decline began from there to the next date at peak. Third date (Oct 15) did not work - failed to serve as a turning point and price continued declining. Fourth date (Oct 22) arrived one day early (Oct 21) and served as the low - from there a rally of approximately 10% began at peak though it reversed before the next date. Fifth date (Oct 29-30) was a double date - arrived with a decline and began a rally toward the first November turning date (Nov 4).
risk_notes: November is seasonally one of the two most bearish months for oil - countertrend long positions carry elevated risk
Nov 11 carries the highest probability signal in the entire report at 82% for decline - be particularly cautious with long exposure around this date
A break below $55.30 previous lows could accelerate declines toward $43.40 - a potential 30%+ drop from current levels
Geopolitical events can override seasonal and cyclical patterns in oil - maintain awareness of Middle East and OPEC+ developments
The 20-week and 50-week moving averages both acting as resistance confirms the bearish structure - avoid fighting this trend without clear reversal signals
Even the Oct 22 turning date that triggered a 10% rally from the low reversed before the next turning date - rallies in a downtrend tend to be sharp but short-lived
